samples.question: So do you usually wear clothes in your favorite color?
samples.transcript: For clothing, that is a different story because my skin tone is kind of dark. So I have to specifically go for colors that kind of flatter it. So for me, it would be very muted colors. I do not usually go for vibrant ones because it also does not suit my vibe. Right? So I do not want to like carry myself in a way that is a bit, you know, not who I am. Yeah.
samples.transcript_original: Uh, for clothing, that's a different story because my skin tone is kind of dark. So I have to specifically go for colors that kind of flatter it. So for me, it would be very muted colors. Uh, I don't usually go for vibrant ones because it also doesn't suit my vibe. Right? So I don't want to like carry myself in a way that's a bit, you know, not who I am. Yeah.
samples.transcript_cleaned: For clothing, that is a different story because my skin tone is kind of dark. So I have to specifically go for colors that kind of flatter it. So for me, it would be very muted colors. I do not usually go for vibrant ones because it also does not suit my vibe. Right? So I do not want to like carry myself in a way that is a bit, you know, not who I am.

samples.question: So are there any colors that have a special meaning in your country?
samples.transcript: I mean, the obvious answer would be red. You would see that ubiquitously in Ted's holiday and in very, you know, jubilant occasions of Vietnam, like wedding ceremonies or other celebrations. You know, I think red kind of, you know, in Vietnamese culture means something like not just jubilation, but also joy and prosperity. So that is why it is like a very common pick for those occasions. Yeah. Okay.
samples.transcript_original: Um, I mean, the obvious answer would be red. You would see that ubiquitously in Ted's holiday and in very, uh, you know, jubilant occasions of Vietnam, like wedding ceremonies or other celebrations. You know, I think red kind of, you know, in Vietnamese culture means something like not just jubilation, but also joy and prosperity. So that's why it's like a very common pick for those occasions. Yeah. Okay.

So that is why it is like a very common pick for those occasions.

samples.question: So do you think different types of people like different colors?
samples.transcript: Mmm, that is a pretty interesting one. I have never really thought about that.
samples.transcript_original: Mmm, that's a pretty interesting one. I've never really thought about that.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Mmm, that is a pretty interesting one. I have never really thought about that.

samples.question: I think people like naturally gravitate towards different colors, based on like historically how they have like get exposed to them, you know?
samples.transcript: For example, if someone, you know, as a child, and as someone as a child, they learned art and they tended to use, very vibrant colors. Maybe they would grow up and, picking those colors more. But if someone has gone through like a very, I would say difficult period in their lives, then maybe they would have the tendency to pick, more muted or like, you know, just monotone colors just to reflect their, their minds a bit better. Okay.
samples.transcript_original: Uh, for example, if someone, you know, as a child, uh, and as someone as a child, they learned art and they tended to use, uh, very vibrant colors. Maybe they would grow up and, uh, picking those colors more. But if someone has gone through like a very, I would say difficult period in their lives, then maybe they would have the tendency to pick, uh, more muted or like, you know, just monotone colors just to reflect their, uh, their minds a bit better. Okay.

samples.question: So how about in terms of personality?
samples.transcript: I think joyful people, bubbly personalities, they go for, they go for vibrant colors a lot. But having said that, there is still some exception where people get experimental and they, they want to try out with, you know, color schemes that are not really showy, not really flashy. You know, I do respect their picks, but I think that, you know, it is best to go for the colors that describe your personality, the clearest to people.
samples.transcript_original: Um, I think joyful people, bubbly personalities, uh, they go for, um, they go for vibrant colors a lot. You know, I do respect their picks, but I think that, you know, it's best to go for the colors that describe your personality, uh, the clearest to people.

samples.question: So, how do your students react to the photos when you show them?
samples.transcript: They usually mistake my sister for my girlfriend, which I always have to clarify, you know, I mean, she looks so much younger than me. I just kind of, it is hard for me to comprehend why they would make such a mistake. All right. So that is the end of the second part of the test.
samples.transcript_original: They usually mistake my sister for my girlfriend, which I always have to clarify, you know, I mean, she looks so much younger than me. I just kind of, it's hard for me to comprehend why they would make such a mistake. All right. So that is the end of the second part of the test.
samples.transcript_cleaned: They usually mistake my sister for my girlfriend, which I always have to clarify, you know, I mean, she looks so much younger than me. I just kind of, it is hard for me to comprehend why they would make such a mistake. All right. So that is the end of the second part of the test.

samples.question: So do you think it is easy to take good photographs?
samples.transcript: I mean as an artist, I am kind of tempted to say that it is because you know, there is kind of this tension between artists who paint pictures and photographers who just take photos. That is like we are the people who are creating true art, not them. But you know, after trying out photography for like for a decent amount, I have gotten my fair share of experience in that. I did realize that you know photography also comes with all the sophistication that it comes with of painting. You still have to prepare for the lighting. You still have to make sure the composition is right. Not to mention that you also have to like pay very acute attention to the technical details, like choosing the right lens for the shoot that you want to take. And, when you take photographs, you just do not have that, that leeway with the scene, you know, as an artist, you can set up the scene however you want. Like basically pull it out an image from your head But for photography you have to wait for the right moment And that is actually what makes street photography so fascinating to me you know because you always have to be there be present at the moment and you have to make sure that your camera is ready when there an interesting snap So what are the pros and cons of digital photography All right So I think that nowadays the line between digital photography and the more traditional method to produce photos have been kind of blurred Because nowadays we have a lot of softwares that allow us kind of facilitate the process for us to create any kind of look that we wish for our photos. You can like set up a more traditional lighting setting in Adobe Lightroom and you can, you know, just retouch a photo however you like. As long as you are aware of the, you know, the potential artificial quality that might come with over editing a photo, then I think you should be fine. So that is the pros of digital photography. That is that you have a lot of avenue for editing your photos nowadays. But when it comes to the cons, I think that to some people, especially those who kind of identify themselves as like true artists, it kind of takes away, you know, taking a photo digitally and edit them on a software. It kind of takes away the fun of the process. And it is not like they cannot do the more traditional methods, stick to conventionality anymore, but it is more like they are forced into digital photography nowadays, or else they will not get any customer. They will not get any customer. They will not produce photos quickly enough.

samples.question: When can an image be worth a thousand words?
samples.transcript: This is actually really tricky. I am not so much into literature, you know, so. Let me approach this in a slightly more scientific way.
samples.transcript_original: Um, this is actually really tricky. Um, I'm not so much into literature, you know, so. Let me approach this in a slightly more scientific way.
samples.transcript_cleaned: This is actually really tricky. I am not so much into literature, you know, so. Let me approach this in a slightly more scientific way.

samples.question: So neuroscience, from the neuroscience perspective, I would say that a picture contains a lot of different information, right?
samples.transcript: So when you look at a picture, you are seeing not only the object, but also the kind of environment it is, it is in, the condition, weather condition, lighting conditions, all that, around surrounding the object. And you see the condition of the object itself. So for example, if you were taking a photo of a rusty cup, a rusted cup, then you see that right there on the photo, right?
samples.transcript_original: So when you look at a picture, you're seeing not only the object, but also the kind of environment it is, it is in, uh, the condition, weather condition, lighting conditions, all that, um, around surrounding the object. samples.question: It is something that if you take the linguistic equivalent of it, it would be a few different, a few long paragraphs, right?
samples.transcript: I mean, you have seen like, a lot of examples of that when, in a novel, a, a writer needs to write a very long paragraph just to describe the scene. But you know on the movie adaptation of that is only like a three minute footage a three second footage Right So yeah I think in that case you know sometimes scientifically saying the image kind of communicates information more efficiently It can manage to do that in a very short span of time All right. So one last question.

samples.question: So is a photograph a reliable form of identification?
